content:
Hi Doug, You could find more info about the Junk settings and how you can train Thunderbird to recognize junk messages here: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages

You also need to right click on your account - Settings - Junk Settings - Move new junk messages to: (and select your junk folder)

There is a high probability that your e-mail provider already classified them as spam, so you could enable also the setting - Trust Junk mail headers set by: and then select your providers' classifier.

This might take time, please be patient!

If you want an immediate effect, you can set up a filter like the one on the screenshot. You can start by clicking the Tools> Message Filters from your main menu. Please note the "Clasification" dropdown.

content:
• crea un collegamento a Thunderbird sul Desktop
  • apri la finestra Esegui di Windows con la combinazione di tasti Win+R (permi cioè il tasto Windows sulla tastiera e contemporaneamente il tasto R)
  • digita in Esegui il comando shell:sendto e premi invio
  • si aprirà la cartella SendTo
  • Sposta il collegamento a Thunderbird dal Desktop a SendTo

Adesso dovresti trovare un rimando a Thunderbird nel sotto menu Invia a. Questo collegamento è indipendente dal Destinatario posta che invece è gestito da Windows e dipende dalle impostazioni dei programmi predefiniti.

content: The purest way, assuming Windows, is to use windows file explorer, locate c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming and delete the folder named Thunderbird. Do this after uninstalling thunderbird and it will reinstall clean.

content:
DavidMW said
Sender address is not allowed.. Please verify that your email address is correct in your account settings and try again.

Your picture indicates you're trying to send from the geminisound account over the smtp with the wright47 account credentials. The error indicates that isn't allowed. This is a common issue with multiple accounts: you must have separate smtp servers for each account, and set each account to send on an smtp with a matching User Name:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1350593

content:
I think I finally found the issue, the folderCache.json file. The file contained the entire structure or folders of the IMAP account, (e.g. Inbox, Trash, Junk folders. etc.) I deleted those lines in the file. The IMAP account no longer appears when I launch TB. I created the POP3 account. So far so good. Sent several test emails successfully. Launched and shutdown TB, so far no issues. Looking like the file was the problem.

Thank!!!!

content:
You should have separate gmail smtp servers that are identical except for the User Name (and Description), and set each account to send on the matching smtp. Otherwise, as you find, gmail automatically switches the sending account.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1350593
creator: sfhowes

content:
Thank you sfhowes. You got me looking in the right direction but unfortunately it did not solve the problem.

I failed to mention in the original post that I'm using TB 115.7.0 (64-bit).

When I go to settings, I see the two accounts with different email addresses, which short circuited my analysis.

Your response got me to looking at the "Edit SMTP server ..." selection. And, for account B, I found the user name listed was that for account A. So I changed the user name and set the description to be unique for account B.

Returning to account A and checking the server info, I found that both the description and the user name for account B had "propagated" to account A. So I changed account A to a unique description and the correct user name, returned to account B and found the account B info had been changed to that for account A.

At least for this version of TB, it seems that the critical item is the server name and that TB only allows one instance. At least for things as I have them currently set.

Any thoughts on what to do now?
creator: ramjr66

content: You can't fix it by just changing settings in Edit SMTP Server. Account Settings, Outgoing Server (SMTP), create 2 gmail smtp servers, then select each account in the left pane of Account Settings and point to the correct server in the smtp drop-down. Instructions are in the link in my first reply.
creator: sfhowes

This seems to have solved the prolem.

content: My first observation is that port 587 is usually associated with authentication, such as STARTTLS (or maybe SSL/TLS - whatever works). Many email hosts want confirmation that this is a legit account. There may be more, but that is my first thought. This should be set for all of the SMTP server setups.
creator: davidsk

content:
So it sounds like you want me to use STARTTLS as the authentication methgod in the outgoing SMTP. I changed to that & The email still bounced back to me with the following:

This message was created automatically by mail delivery software.

A message that you sent could not be delivered to one or more of its recipients. This is a permanent error. The following address(es) failed: 

 louislyons@msn.com    host msn-com.olc.protection.outlook.com [104.47.51.225]    SMTP error from remote mail server after pipelined end of data:    550 5.7.1 Unfortunately, messages from [216.154.220.159] weren't sent. Please contact your Internet service provider since part of their network is on our block list (S3150). You can also refer your provider to http://mail.live.com/mail/troubleshooting.aspx#errors. [AM7EUR03FT050.eop-EUR03.prod.protection.outlook.com 2024-01-31T19:06:17.823Z 08DC225BC7DEE090]
creator: harold21

content: Well, the suggestion for STARTTLS was just my first thought, since it seems authentication is a likely problem and you are sending unauthenticated messages. The solution might be port 465 and SSL/TLS. I don't know the defined settings of your email provider, and even those may be wrong, as we see that issue daily. The error message is a wide one: 550 7.2.1 - more info at https://sendlayer.com/docs/error-550-5-7-1-unauthorized-email-rejection/ your email provider is on a black list, so I would start there. We have seen many posts where the sender's email address is self-hosted and does not have appropriate DKIM and/or SPF settings on the server -- something only the email provider can do or the account owner with direct access to cpanel.
creator: davidsk
